Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Modulation of a Neuroendocrine System by Endocrine Disruptors - BPA effects on GnRH neuron development, physiology and reproductive behavior in teleost fish
Award.AbstractNarration:
Neurons releasing Gonadotropin releasing hormone (GnRH) in the brain are the main controllers of reproduction and reproductive behavior in most vertebrates, including humans. Reproductive health, fertility and behavioral problems have been linked to abnormal development and function of the GnRH neuronal system. There is increasing evidence that endocrine disrupting chemicals, such as bisphenol A (BPA) - a synthetic estrogen in our environment - have deleterious effects on the reproductive systems and behaviors in many species. This study addresses how GnRH neuron development, physiology and reproductive behavior, are altered by chronic exposure to low levels of BPA. This project will use transgenic fish models, having GnRH neurons tagged with green fluorescent proteins, to address effects of chronic BPA exposure on: a) embryonic GnRH neuron development, b) physiology of adult GnRH neurons, and c) mating and social behavior. Experiments will use neural electrical recordings, confocal imaging, immunohistochemistry and behavioral observations. The project will result in understanding how endocrine disruptors modulate the GnRH system and suggest potential solutions for reproductive problems like ovarian dysfunction, miscarriages, pre-term births, precocious puberty and Kallman's syndrome.

This study will be the first to address the impact of BPA on GnRH neuron development, physiology, and function, in conjunction with whole animal behavior. Data and protocols from the study will be available to the academic community and the general public via the University of Puget Sound archives and the lab website (http://sidslab.wikispaces.com/). Undergraduate researchers will receive broad neuroscience training at the cell, circuit, and whole-animal levels, with ecological perspectives. K-12 students will be involved in intensive workshops, ongoing collaborative observational studies and regular seminars through outreach at public schools. The plan is to Excite, Educate, Engage by making participants excited about science, educated about neuroscience and the impact of environmental toxins, and engaged with the community and the environment.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Reproduction and allied reproductive behaviors are essential for the propagation and success of species. In most vertebrates reproductive physiology and behavior are controlled by a set of neurons called the Gonadotropin-Releasing Hormone neurons (GnRH). These neurons control many functions including regulating reproductive hormones, mate choice, social behavior and mating.

 

With the increase in use of plastics, animals (including us humans) are under constant exposure to different plastic monomers such as Bisphenols (BPA, BPF, BPS etc.). While there have been many studies looking at toxicological effects of these compounds, not many studies examine the effects of chronic, low-dose exposure to such chemicals. With this grant we examined the development of the GnRH neuron system, its perturbation by Bisphenols, effects on social and reproductive behavior as well as cross-generational effects. The studies were carried out on a genetically engineered zebrafish and medaka  (small fresh water fish species) with the GnRH neurons tagged with a green fluorescent protein. This allowed for easy visualization of these neurons both within the growing embryo, as well as in adult dissected brains. We used zebrafish/medaka as models for a few reasons ? i) easy to maintain in the lab; ii) reach sexual maturity in 3 months, allowing for generational studies; iii) transparent embryos, allowing for investigating brain development without damaging the embryo; iv) ease of use with undergraduate students.

 

Intellectual Merit: Some salient findings

i) Low dose exposure to 200ng/ml Bisphenol A alters development of gonadotropin-releasing hormone3 neurons and locomotor behavior.

ii) These effects persist across 2 generations (even if the offspring are themselves never directly treated with BPA)

iii) Embryonic BPA exposure affects locomotor behavior in young fish larvae

iv) Timing and duration of BPA exposure during embryogenesis alters the cross-generational BPA effects on neural development, larval behavior and adult fertility

v) Social behavior is affected by embryonic BPA exposure

vi) Mechanistically, BPA is acting via an estrogenic pathway.

vii) Early stress hormone exposure in the embryo affects the development of the GnRH neuron system

 

Broader Impact: This project supported the training of over 40 undergraduate students, 1 postdoctoral scholar and 1 technician over the course of 5 years. Three peer-reviewed manuscripts have already been published (with 4 undergraduate student authors) and 2 other manuscripts are under preparation.  The grant also aided the outreach to local high schools and middle schools. 4 summer high school students were trained in the lab during the project. This grant helped reshape the curriculum in the university with new lab-based modules and an entire ?Methods in Neuroscience? course. Neuroethics has also become an integral part of the curriculum.  A website has been created detailing the various practices in the lab, which allows members of the public to look at dissection techniques and protocols. The PI has also been constantly involved in Art-Science salons and presented the work at these forums to bring the science to a larger audience.
